title: 104_s1670
content: The "Common Sense Middle Class Tax Relief Act of 1996" is the short title of the Act. It includes an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Section 2 introduces a deduction for higher education expenses under a new section 220 for tuition and fees. The "Common Sense Middle Class Tax Relief Act of 1996" introduces a deduction for qualified higher education expenses paid by an individual during the taxable year. The deduction is limited to $10,000, with a phase-in provision for taxable years beginning in 1996. Additionally, the deduction is subject to a limitation based on modified adjusted gross income. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses is subject to a reduction based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The reduction amount is calculated based on a ratio of the taxpayer's income over a certain threshold. Adjusted gross income for tax purposes is determined without considering specific sections and deductions, with inflation adjustments applied for taxable years after 1998. Adjusted gross income for tax purposes is determined without considering specific sections and deductions, with inflation adjustments applied for taxable years after 1998. Qualified higher education expenses are defined under this section, with adjustments made for cost-of-living and rounding to the nearest multiple of $5,000. The term 'qualified higher education expenses' refers to tuition and fees required for enrollment or attendance at an institution of higher education for the taxpayer, spouse, or dependent eligible student. Expenses related to sports, games, or hobbies are excluded unless part of a degree program. The term 'eligible student' refers to a student who meets specific requirements under the Higher Education Act of 1965 and is carrying at least one-half of a degree program's academic expenses. The term 'eligible student' refers to a student who is carrying at least one-half the normal full-time workload for their course of study or is enrolled in a course to improve job skills. Taxpayers must include the eligible student's name, age, and taxpayer identification number on their tax return to claim a deduction. The term 'institution of higher education' is defined as an institution eligible for programs under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965. No double benefit is allowed for qualified higher education expenses if a deduction is already claimed under another tax provision. No deduction allowed for individuals with a deduction under section 151 for another taxpayer in the same calendar year. A deduction for qualified higher education expenses is limited to the amount exceeding the exclusion under section 135. Deduction under subsection (a) allowed only for the taxable year. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses is limited to expenses in connection with enrollment at an institution of higher education during the taxable year. Prepayments are allowed for expenses related to an academic term beginning in the taxable year or the first 3 months of the next year. Adjustment is made for scholarships and veterans' benefits reducing the amount of qualified expenses considered for deduction. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses is reduced by amounts received for the taxable year as a qualified scholarship, educational assistance allowance under specific chapters of title 38, or a payment for educational expenses exempt from income taxation. No deduction is allowed for married individuals filing separately. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses is subject to certain conditions. Married individuals must file a joint return to qualify, and nonresident aliens must be treated as resident aliens. The Secretary may establish regulations for compliance. The deduction for higher education tuition and fees is allowed in computing adjusted gross income. Section 220 is amended to include this deduction. A conforming amendment is made to the table of sections. The amendments made by Section 220 allow for the deduction of higher education tuition and fees in computing adjusted gross income. Section 127 is also amended to exclude employer-provided educational assistance programs, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1994.
